div1.head: Letter from the Jefé de Sanidad to the Local Sanitary Officers, July 20, 1908
div1.opener:
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
xxxx
CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER.
Jefetura.
Havana, July 20, 1908.
To Local Sanitary Officers:
div1.p:
As many exaggerated and erroneous accounts have been circu-
lated in the newspapers about the occurrence of yellow fever in
Santiago and Daiquirí, it is thought that an exact statement of the
cases which have occurred since the first of April, the beginning of
the present epidemic year, will be of interest. No case of this
disease has occurred in Havana or in any of the six provinces of the
island except Oriente during that time, the last occurrence, with the
exceptions noted below, having been the brief and promptly extin-
guished outbreak among the American troops stationed in the city of
Santa Clara, of which the first case occurred on February 9th and
the last on February 18th. The history of the outbreak in Oriente
is as follows:

On April 21st Fructuoso Valverde, a Spaniard, was taken sick
at Daiquirí and came on the 22d to Santiago and was admitted for
treatment at the hospital of the Colonia Española, where he was dis-
covered by the sanitary authorities and the case put under observa-
tion. This man had come from Daiquirí to Santiago on April 15th
and had stayed two days in a hotel within 200 meters of the spot
where the preceeding case of Feb. 11th occurred, returning to Daiquirí
on the 17th. His infection is therefore credited to Santiago. The
symptoms being mild, the diagnosis was so much in doubt, that Dr.
2-
Juan Guiteras, president of the Board of Diagnosis of Contagious
Diseases, was sent to Santiago, and pronounced it yellow fever on
May 1st. Measures were promptly taken to disinfect the buildings
in which the patient lived at Daiquirí, and the boat in which he had
come to Santiago, as well as all buildings entered by him in San-
tiago after the beginning of his sickness. Subsequent events, how-
ever, have demonstrated that owing probably to the delay in arriving
at a diagnosis, the measures of fumigation taken at Daiquirí were
not successful in destroying all infected mosquitoes, and the focus
now existing at that place, as well as the two subsequent cases occur-
ring in Santiago on May 13th and June 4th, must be ascribed to the
failure of the fumigation there and in Santiago.

An elaborate system of medical inspections, together with an
efficient organization for mosquito work were instituted at Santiago,
and as no case has occurred in that city in more than six weeks, it
is believed that the infection is extinguished there. Mosquito work
was begun in Daiquirí and a medical inspector sent there, but he
abandoned his post after a few days stay, and a second inspector
sent to this position remained less than a month. In order to keep
this point under observation, inspectors were sent there at intervals,
and in the case histories sent by the Special Medical inspector,
Dr. Agostini, about the 20th of June to this office, a case was
found which excited the suspicion of the Chief Sanitary Officer.
A second inspection was then ordered, Dr. Cartaya, the medical scout
on duty in Santiago, being sent to Daiquirí where he arrived on
July 1st and found a case of yellow fever, the diagnosis of which
was confirmed by autopso the next day. Ten other cases have been
3-
confirmed, and it is probable from the investigations of Dr. Aris-
tides Agramonte who was sent from Havana to make further investiga-
tions, there have been several unrecognized cases antecedent to it.
Active measures of fumigation and mosquito destruction were at once
instituted upon the recognition of this focus, first under the super-
vision of Special Commissioner, Captain H. D. Thomason, Medical Corps,
U. S. Army, and later under Major P. C. Fauntleroy, Medical Corps,
U. S. Army, who has been sent from this office to take charge at
Daiquirí as a Special Commissioner.

Owing to the isolated position of the iron mines at Daiquirí
and the fact that the population is composed almost entirely of em-
ployees of the Spanish-American Iron Company, while communication with
the outside world is limited to a few difficult trails leading to
Santiago and by a boat belonging to the company, the circumstances
seemed peculiarly favorable for the application of a local quarantine
by land as well as sea. This was ordered by the National Sanitary
Board with the approval of the Provisional Governor on July 7th, and
it is believed to be entirely efficient in securing the observation
for the necessary period of all non-immunes leaving the infected focus.
At the same time a stop has been put to the admission of non-immunes
to the infected locality. There is every evidence that these steps
will be promptly successful, and it is hoped by the end of the current
month that the infection of yellow fever which lingers in only one
exttemity of the republic, will be extinguished throughout its terri-
tory.
